definition: meet and greet
to appear/also written 現|现[xian4]
to see/to meet/to appear (to be sth)/to interview
face/side/surface/aspect/top/classifier for flat surfaces such as drums, mirrors, flags etc
can/to be possible/to be able to/will/to be likely to/to be sure to/to assemble/to meet/to gather/to see/union/group/association/CL:個|个[ge4]/a moment (Taiwan pr. for this sense is [hui3])
to balance an account/accountancy/accounting

sentences.english: I know him only by sight.
So Japan had invited Ggong to have his fans meeting there.
sentences.chinese: 所以日方邀請孔劉來日本舉行影迷見面會。

sentences.english: And for the presentation, if it's not on Friday, it will be on Monday at the latest.
sentences.chinese: 至於見面會，如果不在週五，那麼最遲也在下週一。

sentences.english: Talks and laughs merrily the conference for played the families to make the good impression.
sentences.chinese: 談笑風生的見面會給玩家們留下了良好的印象。

sentences.english: The President took a short meet-and-greet walk to the restaurant.
sentences.chinese: 總統到酒店出席了一個簡短見面會。

sentences.english: Then I turned the meeting over to Gloria.
sentences.chinese: 然後，我讓格洛里亞在見面會上講話。

definition: the number of showings of a movie, play etc/screening/performance
to open (a conference)/to inaugurate
to ratchet up/to raise (expectations etc)/to increase (a quota, a position in the market etc)/to up the ante/(computing) to encode
vocal recital or concert
bean vermicelli/mung bean starch noodles/Chinese vermicelli/cellophane noodles/CL:把[ba3]/fan (loanword)/enthusiast for sb or sth
to go on stage/fig. to appear on the scene/used in advertising to mean new product
to depart as quick as a flash/flash mob
to rush (to do sth urgent)/to try to be the first/to forestall
(originally) to provide assistance/(more recently) to show one's support (for a singing idol etc)
to exercise/to move about/to operate/to use connections (personal influence)/loose/shaky/active/movable/activity/campaign/maneuver/behavior/CL:項|项[xiang4],個|个[ge4]
to enter the venue/to enter the arena/(aviation) to approach the airfield/(investing) to get into the market
face to face
to plan/to lay out/to design
the scene (of a crime, accident etc)/(on) the spot/(at) the site
on the eve of/to be about to/to be on the verge of
spectators/audience/visitors (to an exhibition etc)
